issues.title: Addressing Sergio's comment
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
Addressing Sergio's comment raised during WG adoption poll:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ccamp/_coq7CbVgOqfV3f7500_hH0g-Dk/

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body: I think we need to review the text and align the description with the scope of the draft (Ethernet TE and client topology)

issues.title: Addressing Tom Petch's comments
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
> The YANG module is totally devoid of references, which has to be fixed, at least in part, at some stage and the earlier it is fixed, the less time consuming reviewing is.
> 

- [x] add references when applicable

References added when applicable: see PR #6 

> s.5 says there is no open issue in this version.  The text gives the lie to this with 'open issue' in four places
> 

- [x] remove section 5: all the issues described in section 5 have been addressed either in this revision or in previous revisions

Section 5 removed because all the issues described in section 5 have been addressed either in this revision or in previous revisions: see PR #10 

> there are YANG statements commented out.  The last time I saw this it was because the Author could not make the YANG work
> 

- [x] review the YANG code and track these as open issues in github

Removed all the YANG statements comments out: see PR #6 

> It is another of those module that is really 100 or so independent YANG fragments in a different order to those other modules that are really 100 or so independent YANG fragments.  As was said in a recent IESG review, it is a shame we cannot go back and change the TEAS i.e. they got the underlying structure wrong:-( 
> 

- [x] clarify in the draft that the multiple augment statements to augment the TE label/bandwidth information are based on the guidelines provided by section 6 of RFC8795 (see for example the text in otn-topology draft).


Draft updated to clarify that the multiple augment statements to augment the TE label/bandwidth information are based on the guidelines provided by section 6 of RFC8795: see PR #10 

> the choice of YANG prefix makes comprehension harder
> 

- [x] align the prefix with the outcome of the prefix discussion on the mailing list

See #3 

See: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ccamp/o6HYzsxzNKjWRJFa5CO9bYNqHs4/

issues.title: Alignment with Packet TE Topology
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
Align the I-D and YANG model to augment the Packet TE Topology model instead:

```
                      +-------------------------+
         TE generic   |    ietf-te-topology     |
                      +------------+------------+
                                   ^
                                   |
                                   | Augments
                                   |
                      +------------+------------+
         Packet TE    | ietf-te-topology-packet |
                      +------------+------------+
                                   ^
                                   |
                                   | Augments
                                   |
                      +------------+------------+
         Ethernet     |  ietf-eth-te-topology   |
                      +-------------------------+

```

See also [draft-busizheng-teas-yang-te-mpls-topology](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-busizheng-teas-yang-te-mpls-topology)

pulls.title: YANG updates for the -05 version
pulls.author: italobusi
pulls.body:
Updated to support multi-layer topology instances: fix #5 

Fixed YANG model prefix: fix #3 

Added references when applicable: see #2 

Removed all the YANG statements comments out: see #2 

Aligned with TE bandwidth, label range and label augmentations in other topology models

Fixed other YANG language nits.

comments.author: samans
comments.body:
[e-error.out.txt](https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/files/12588660/e-error.out.txt)
[e.json.txt](https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/files/12588661/e.json.txt)
[e-error.json.txt](https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/files/12588662/e-error.json.txt)

e.json.txt contains a small instance example that passes validation with yanglint
e-error.json.txt contains a small example that doesn't pass yanglint
e-error.out-txt contains the error message from yanglint showing the must statement fails.
Need to check (testing some JSON examples) the correctness of this must statement

would it be "etht" if to align with the conventions for TE-based models?
Or are you concerned about possible confusion that "etht" means "ethernet topology"?

For the reference,  we currently have: otnt, flexgt, tet, and oit...

For Packet TE and MPLS-TE topology the prefixes are tet-pkt and tet-mpls (although Tom Petch has complained on the list that they should be pkt-tet and mpls-tet instead)

For Packet and MPLS-TE, it seems that it is need to avoid confusion between TE and non-TE topologies

Not fully sure about Ethernet ...

Maybe we can use etht here and leave the xxx-tet exceptions only to the YANG models developed in TEAS WG ...

Any suggestion?

pulls.title: Draft updates for the -05 version
pulls.author: italobusi
pulls.body:
Draft converted to kramdown

Updated Xufeng affiliation

Added Chaode as author

Updated abstract and introduction to clarify the scope of the draft: fix https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/issues/1

Restructured sections 2, 3 and 4

Clarified that TE bandwidth and label augmentations are based on the guidelines in section 6 of RFC8795: fix https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/issues/2

Removed section 5: fix https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/issues/2

Aligned with latest YANG model: see PR https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/pull/6

Updated list of authors and contributors

Note 1: Diff between the version converted to kramdown and the -04 uploaded to IETF: [draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang.diff.zip](https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/files/12580704/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang.diff.zip)

Note 2: Diff between the new version and the -04 uploaded to IETF: [Side-by-side diff](https://www.ietf.org/rfcdiff?url1=draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang&url2=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/italobusi/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/kramdown/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang.txt)

comments.author: sergiobelotti
comments.body: I've put some comments that does not preclude the approval. One question: this version does not contain yet the modification needed for single instance topology for multi-layer , right?

same question as on the other pull request for YANG models 
"eth-tet" or "etht" as the model prefix?
To align with the resolution of the discussion in PR #6

adding "itself" --> This document describes a YANG data model for Ethernet networks when
   used either as a client-layer network of an underlay transport
   network (e.g., an Optical Transport Network (OTN)) or as a transport
   network itself. The meaning is : it can be a client of a transport nW or it can be a transport network it self.
when used as a client-layer network.....or as a transport network technology
not clear to me the comment, Italo. I agree with Aihua it should be etht in alignement with others , recently the Optical Impairment with "oit"

Aligned with the resolution in PR #6 

See: https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-eth-client-te-topo-yang/pull/10/commits/e0703159284b753b704cfb36bac7988e74bc7865
